Author: mparris
Content:
In this article, I demonstrate the problem with referring to any one function as just "OPC-UA"... Two people may think they are taking about the same OPC-UA function but not.

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/what-technologies-ready-your-iiot-architecture-matthew-parris/

OPC-UA has over 200 functions (per my count). Were you able to port over all functions in 45 hours? If not, which ones did you tackle?

Author: ravil1
Content:
If you need to touch every "function", that would be complete re-writing.
Fortunately, the open62541 library is cross-platform, designed to be portable. So most part will just work when you build it for another target. 
In this case, porting was about using TCP stack specific for this embedded RTOS, disabling un-used OPC UA features to minimize memory usage and optimization of using memory heap. Creating of OPC UA variables in the address space was just one day.

Author: ravil1
Content:
Great analysis, enjoyed reading it!
And you are right, OPC UA is not flat and simple, you might need to clarify when somebody mentions OPC UA - do you mean Alarms/Events, History, or PubSub? For example, if you assume that every OPC UA Server would have support for PubSub, will be disappointed.
In my opinion, OPC UA Data Access is now at TRL level 9. So it is worth making data available over OPC UA - then any SCADA/HMI can access it. I see the most value of OPC UA as of today in this. And don't think that MQTT can replace OPC UA in this use case.
In my understanding, the main consumers of data from devices are SCADA/HMI applications. With IIoT, another consumer appears - cloud-based. For the latter, MQTT of course is a better choice. 
Keeping in mind that for SCADA/HMI we still need OPC UA, should we add support for the MQTT right into any device? I don't think so. For example, in my case with this embedded device: resources are limited, hard to support both OPC UA and MQTT. Independently, or OPC UA  PubSub over MQTT - does not matter, in both cases we need to load the MQTT library into RAM.
My approach is to use middleware applications like ogamma Visual Logger for OPC to receive data from OPC UA Servers and publish it to MQTT brokers. You can argue then about what the format should be - SparkPlugB, or OPC UA PubSub JSON, or something else - that is another story.

Author: mparris
Content:
My opinion is that all IIoT devices should support both OPC-UA data access and MQTT SparkplugB, that is until a technology becomes more ubiquitous than these two.

Maybe for a resource limited device, only allow one to be active at a time, which would enable the customer to choose.

I'd be interested to know which requires more resources: OPC-UA DA Server, or an MQTT publisher with sparkplug.

Author: ravil1
Content:
Anyway, I think it is better to have OPC UA as the primary data source. Because OPC UA has more features. I think it is possible to map/convert from MQTT to OPC UA without losing anything. like converting int16 to int64. But not possible to map OPC UA to MQTT without losing some information. Like when you convert from int64 to int16, it works only for some range of data.
It is not clear to me, in MQTT, how you configure sampling rate, and what variables/tags should be published? Is that mostly hardcoded? In OPC UA, all this can be done from the client side. And how do you configure, what broker to publish to?  MQTT assumes that there are many subscribers - how do you know, what are these subscribers interested in? And how do you control access rights - allow only some subscribers to have access to some topics? Or all these features are not required in reality by the end-users - it is OK all have the same access to the same set of data, at the same rate? 
Also, I believe MQTT introduces inevitable delays in message delivery time comparing to OPC UA. I tried to use MQTT as a transport / cloud-based relay in some proof-of-concept project, the delay was very noticeable, and ended up creating a custom broker-kind app using WebSockets as a transport.

Author: mparris
Content:
@zackscriven I think the great questions Ravil brings up should be included in a video requested by @Anders Gustav comparing OPC and SpB, and when to use each.

Regarding message delivery delays, are your comparing a point-to-point OPC-UA DA client server connection to an MQTT connection between two devices and linked by a broker?

Have you compared MQTT i a chain of two pairs of UA client/servers? There should be more propagation delay with UA due to the polling nature of client server: the second pair would need a publish rate twice the speed of the first pair to not delay the data.  MQTT doesn't have this issue as a publish will traverse across a string of brokers as fast as reasonably possible.

This quickly becomes apparent if you are trying to integrate data from the plant floor up through multiple levels of the Enterprise. OPC-UA's only TRL-9 solution is client server data access, which will typically add propagation delays at every level.

Author: ravil1
Content:
I was writing about the message delivery delay issue not comparing it to OPC UA. It was in the proof-of-concept project for the new product, a kind of TCP tunneling, primarily intended to be used to connect from the local OPC UA client app to the OPC UA Server running in a remote site, behind the firewall. The idea is, there would be Agent kind apps running in both hosts, client-side and server-side, and the broker in the cloud. The client would connect to the client-side agent, as it would connect to the OPC UA Server, and the agent would redirect messages to the remote server-side agent via the Broker, and then the remote agent would send that message to the server. In the same way, the response would be returned from the server to the client.
For this application initially, I tried to use MQTT, but it was noticeable slow even when both the client and server and broker are in the local network.  When the broker was located in the cloud, it was too slow to be useable.
Then I implemented my own broker, with connections using WebSockets, and that was fast.
I think the MQTT broker does not send messages to the subscribers immediately, instead, it saves them in the queue, and then periodically sends qualifying topic messages to the subscribers. And that period can be significant I guess. I am not sure how MQTT clients communicate with the broker, probably they do poll it periodically.
In terms of the delay context as you considered, you are right that the publishing interval should be short to minimize the delay when you chain OPC UA Servers. I would not expect that there would be too many chained levels, maybe 2 or three I guess. In most cases, I think just one federating gateway server would be used.  I don't think that each enterprise level (MES, ERP) would need its own federating gateway server. I might be wrong though.

Author: ravil1
Content:
Hi Anders, 
I cannot claim that fully understand the unified namespace concept. I guess it is a way to represent process control data from different sources in a context, like in a  hierarchically organized way, for example, Enterprise XYZ, Plant 123, Line ABC, Unit 123, Pump A, Inlet Pressure, or something like that.
Can OPC UA be used for that? Sure, as a specification, it has everything to build such a namespace. It has an auto-discovery mechanism, the standard way to represent any informaiton model, aggregating capabilities (using gateway servers on top of lower layer servers). Also, your namespace can be not just static, it supports versioning of your address space, you can even change your address space at runtime: there are special services for that (AddNodes, AddReferences). Alarms, history - all is possible. BTW - using MQTT, how can you query historical data? Support for complex data types - yes. Authentication and authorization - yes. BTW, In MQTT, not sure how to implement authorization - probably it is not possible at all and it is the way this feature is presented as Democratized access to data. - any subscriber can access any data. Speaking of Authentication - you can do it with just username/password, tokens like OAuth, or user certificates. Or you want to transfer files - yes, you can do this too with OPC UA. Or call methods remotely - yes.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is true theoretically, but far from the truth in practice.

[A sampling of transports by available products or announced OPC-UA pub/sub support]
Beckhoff TwinCAT 3 Pub/Sub Extension:  UDP
Siemens S7-1500 "LOpcUa" Pub/Sub Function Block:  UDP
Hilscher netX OPC-UA + TSN:  UDP
Iconics IoTWorX OPC-UA Pub/Sub and Azure client:  AMQP
B&R X20 OPC-UA + TSN:  MQTT

I get it.  The OPC-UA standard takes an "all-the-above" approach allowing users to deploy the optimal transport of their choice.  For example, they may use UDP on edge, but MQTT or AMQP to the cloud.  The problem with this, just as with information modeling, is that it's simultaneously not prescriptive and practical enough for mass adoption.  The amount of variation in which this standard can be implemented negates the benefits of using a standard.  It virtually guarantees that engineering will be required to convert transport and/or payload.  This is why well over 90% of the market for OPC-UA is TCP Binary Client/Server.

Unless someone comes up with some sort of widely available HighByte + Kepware -like swiss army knife platform that can accept every flavor of OPC-UA (and companion protocols) with relative ease and repeatability, I can't see this ever taking off for brownfield.  It's even a challenge for greenfield.  Without some mythical unicorn platform, every implementation will require extensive engineering.  It's so extensive that it's like designing one's own protocol.

Author: ravil1
Content:
@js, regarding *"This is true theoretically, but far from the truth in practice"*: any specification is all about theory. When we compare specifications, we compare theories. In practice, it is often about the "results war" as it was mentioned here multiple times correctly. But these applications with PubSub over MQTT are coming. Development Kits are done in multiple languages. If there are no enough released products yet, does not mean the spec is bad and has no future.
It is valid to choose to use whatever else is available today (for example SparkPlugB over MQTT) if that conforms with all your requirements. Why not. I think it all depends on use cases. OPC UA as correctly mentioned is verbose, can be too universal, tries to cover a wide range of use cases. If your particular use case does not have such wide requirements, there is no advantage in choosing it. No need to buy 10 tonnes truck, if all your load is below 0.5 tonnes.
Anyhow, somehow China and South Korea promoted OPC UA as a national standard. Maybe SparkPlug is too, need to check (this time it is sarcasm, sorry). It is one of the requirements for Industry 4.0 (not in general meaning, I mean European program). 
Concluding, I don't think one eliminates the other. Rather opposite. Author: mparris
Content:
Thanks for your contributions.

You mention that the merit of a spec could be judged at the theoretical level, but I think this misses the point of the spec is to become useable products.

I understand the fascination with OPC-UA, because I was there about a year ago. It is a deep well providing many topics to learn about.  But that is also it's downfall.

I suspect if you surveyed the makeup of those writing the spec, were end-users there defining the use cases, or was it made up of OEMs creating solutions that they think the market needs? Then the question is why all these OEMs that created the standards haven't even deployed the technologies that they thought was useful?

It sounds like you haven't implemented SparkplugB yet, but are interested. If you do implement it, my only request is that you take an honest assessment at how long it takes you to incorporate into your product vs the time it took you to develop the OPC-UA side.

I've been working with Matrikon (your ole buddies) and their innovative OPC-UA product Matrikon Data Broker took years to develop and it still is not complete.

Evaluating a spec should also include how easy it is to implement to have a better chance at market adoption. For if a spec is not accepted in the market, how good can it be?

Case in point: SparkplugB was released on paper in 2016. Pub/Sub was released a only year later in 2017. For Pub/Sub MQTT being available four years, all it has to show for it are a couple SDKs. Compare to SparkplugB, which has products at every level of the automation stack.

This begs the question, why has the market accepted one and not the other, and how much of this is to be blamed by the spec?

Author: mparris
Content: Any good product manager know that controlling what to include is less important than knowing what to exclude. This is where OPC-UA has struggled... Having so many people spend time to develop so many options to require more time for vendors to determine which of these features will be useful in the market. In my opinion, this is why OPC-UA is not lightweight; it is a heavy burden on the entire market because they don't have the expertise or willpower to focus the market.

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content:
It seems like something went terribly wrong when you tried to use MQTT. We have used MQTT in different scenarios from connected vehicles to IIoT and not once did we have an issue with latency related to MQTT. The projects covered a lot of different network scenarios from using private APNs going through corporate networks and then to the cloud or the other way round. In IIoT scenarios cloud connectivity both regarding throughput as well as latency can be a general issue but this is independent of the protocol (unless throughput is an issue, in which case Google Protocol Buffers as used by Sparkplug can be a big advantage). You can find a little bit older HiveMQ load test with end-to-end latency numbers here: https://www.hivemq.com/benchmark-10-million/ (spoiler: the numbers a re very good)

Regarding how MQTT works: A broker (at least any sane implementation) will send messages right away to all subscribed clients of the respective topic and the clients do not poll the server. That's what the standing MQTT/TCP connection is for. The way the messages are persisted & replicated on the broker cluster depends on the specific broker implementation and can often be configured. The typical MQTT broker is implemented event driven and multi-threaded so you should get a pretty good latency out of it.  Of course the latency will vary between broker implementations. At least HiveMQ does an extremely good job at latency.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's rare that people get to choose what protocols to use on their PLCs.  This typically a function of the PLC itself.  PLCs are more driven by locality, industry, tradition, existing investments, etc.  Do you actually get a choice on what PLC will be used?

I'm assuming they're using some sort of MES app with OPC-UA or Modbus TCP drivers.  If the investment and will is there, they could build a MQTT interface.  If there isn't, you could tell a white lie "Yes, we can use OPC-UA.  Please connect to this OPC-UA Server."  This OPC-UA Server could be an MQTT gateway.

MQTT would be perfect for this.  In fact, it's ideal if that higher-level IT system resides somewhere else across the WAN.  Assuming nodes are connected to a broker, the app would publish to topics in the hierarchy representing where those PLCs reside.  The PLCs would subscribe to those topics.  Whenever the app publishes an update of that 1400 byte payload to a topic, it will be pushed out to the PLCs.  Whatever that 1400 byte payload is, will be written to the PLC at startup and whenever it changes.  Long story short, 1400 bytes move only when 1400 bytes change.

Using OPC-UA, the IT system's client interface will likely be continuously polling tags containing that 1400 byte payload in the server(s) across all 600 PLCs.  I'm going to be a bit of a strawman now.  There are ways to manage subscriptions, but it's rarely done in practice.  Regardless of what happens to those 1400 bytes, assuming there is not a central OPC-UA server, they will get polled every 100ms (or whatever the specified scan rate is) across 600 PLCs.

With Modbus TCP, it's the same thing, but it won't be tags.  It will be registers.  That will be a non-trivial task of consistently mapping into 1400 bytes of memory across 600 PLCs.

Check out this Cirrus Link MQTT Demo video.  1,400 PLCs and 60,000 tags discovered within 15 seconds.  Beautiful things happen when traditional polling is moved to the edge.
https://vimeo.com/257174334

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It's also worthwhile exploring using the native protocol (ADS) with a central gateway.  At scale, a central gateway server may be more economical and easier to manage.

As @trentc - 4.0 Hero LLC mentioned, a code base will have to be developed and deployed to all the devices to use the IoT protocol interface.  The interfaces will also have to be licensed on every device.

As great as it is having native IoT protocol support onboard PLCs, it does not always make things easier in practice.  Some automation companies add this in as an afterthought.  It's like they were built under the assumption that they're for a small project and a small amount of data.  They're not built as the cornerstone of connectivity.  As a result, some interfaces are rife with limitations (e.g., extensive programming required, no en masse selection, flattened structure, tag limitations).  These challenges can make using gateway with a decent native protocol driver appealing.  With automatic tag generation, anything and everything in the controller you may need becomes available.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
There's a well accepted practice that has been around for many years called "deadbanding".  Only transmit the new value when it changes from the last published value by a certain amount - sometimes expressed as a percentage, sometimes as an absolute value.  Similar things can be done on the storage side, although now that storage is relatively cheap this has become less of an issue.  Also, in some cases where the data is used for compliance reporting, you'll also want to send after a certain period of time even if the value hasn't changed (perhaps once per day or once per hour minimum).

Regarding what you transmit (all values or just what changed) definitely just send what changed.  Your topic structure should mirror your individual attributes *or* you can use Sparkplug B and only transmit the changed values on NDATA or DDATA messages.

You'll need to keep some basic state in your PLC logic (last sent value, deadband limit, and perhaps time last sent) and the logic to transmit on exception.

My company is looking to upgrade controls for some sample/development production lines. Historically all controls upgrades in our plants have moved to A-B and Control Logix with Wonderware HMI at the direction of I&E and Maintenance personnel.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Understanding the resistance to change is the first step. Just because you see a better solution does not mean that others see it in the same way.
Take for example this story:
You and your friend are standing at the base of a mountain, in a field near a stream. You say to your friend, We should climb the mountain because the view will be much better from there. Your friend says no. I like this field, and we can go fishing in the stream.
Your fiend is not resisting change.
In order to change, your friend would need to agree that the view from the top of the mountain is better than the field and the stream, AND that the effort of climbing the mountain is worth it to get that gain.
It sounds like you have put forward a great case for why the view from the top of the mountain is better, but no case for why continuing to fish in the stream is bad, and no case for why the effort of climbing the mountain is worth it for the view.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
For someone in maintenance, I would look at preventative maintenance applications.  Many maintenance applications using current technology run their programs based on calendar time (i.e. service 'x' every 'y' months).  Switching to IIoT would allow for use based maintenance to be done easily (i.e. service 'x' every 'y' hours system 'z' is in operation), which is usually the first case.  This would allow them to reduce the amount of work they have to do, while keeping the place running.  

The next one is prescriptive maintenance (i.e. service 'x' when variable 'y' does 'z').  This would allow them to reduce unscheduled maintenance by addressing issues before they become a big problem

After that is predictive maintenance (i.e. service 'x' when the AI tells you to), which takes prescriptive to the next level.  It requires more work, but can really help with unscheduled maintenance.

Lastly is connected predictive maintenance (i.e. service 'x' when the AI tells you it will have a minimum impact on production).  This requires connecting enterprise assets, so it can be much more involved, but it will allow for data to be used from the ERP system to determine when maintenance can be performed to have the smallest impact on the business.

Maintenance can be seen as a cost center and something that interrupts production, if a solution can be framed as addressing both of those issues, then that could be a good way to put it.  Also, to @RickBullotta 's point rip and replace is a big commitment, running something in parallel to the existing system can still be cost effective, and provide the information needed.  Can always replace later.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Quality is going to be an interesting business case going forward as well with the advancements in AI, IIoT, and inspection technologies.  The new inspection technologies allow for every piece to be inspected rather than just taking a selection from the lot, AI can constantly refine the model that decides between good and bad, and IIoT can tie everything together.  This type of inspection method should reduce risk by inspecting the population rather than what you hope is a representative sample, and it should reduce or eliminate product quarantines while waiting for QC, which would have an impact on higher level metrics like ITO and the Cash Cycle.  I'm sure most CFOs know how much each 'x' reduction in those metrics would mean to the company off the top of their heads!

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Unfortunately, the more specialized the industry, the more often you're going to run into this sort of situation.  For potential suppliers looking to break into the industry, there will be significant barriers to entry and a relatively small market, so most of them are going to say screw it and pass on trying to break in.  The fees you're talking about are what you would expect in a monopoly (single suppler) or oligopoly (only a few suppliers) situation.  Not going to be able to arbitrarily increase the size of a market, but forcing suppliers to adopt standards (usually more effective if a large user or an industry group do this) can at least decrease the costs to switch, which can go a long way to breaking a monopoly or oligopoly.

Content: **Question of the Day: **What methods did you use to get buy-in from decision makers in your organization/other organizations? What was it that got the buy-in to start digitally transforming?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Assessments tend to do well....I visited a bunch of factories and developed technology based maturity assessments that were done in conjunction with production floor staff, but intended for management review. This empowers the day-to-day teams as stakeholders in the transformation (they know their pain points better than you in most cases), and when communicating upwards to management it shows a sense of leadership and collaboration....top down tends to break at some point, bottom up (From my experience) is sustainable. Plus, showing metrics to management and a roadmap to take them from Level 1 to Level 3/4/5 is meaningful and demonstrates a vision....which they can then review with you quarterly etc., and also makes them feel in control. Focusing on the technology is problematic, most ops/decision makers aren't well versed, and tend to shy away....but continuous improvement metrics around how tech can improve their operation makes them feel more at ease..

Content: It's far more complicated than that - you need to determine how many times an object will be "consumed" : at least once, exactly once, at most once.  You need to determine if objects might be updated prior to being consumed.  And on and on. These bring along concurrency and other coordination issues.

Author: asthomas
Content: The claim-check pattern works if the sender and receiver both have access to the large item store.  That's not necessarily the case when the sender and receiver are on different networks, especially if the UNS communication path is more than a single hop (e.g., chained brokers).

Author: douga.7429
Content:
First, it's important to recognize that a well-implemented MES, planning, and financial assessments from the ERP system all play a crucial role in evaluating manufacturing performance. We must consider their combined impact on net gross profit margins, schedule adherence, and OEE.

By developing a weighted scoring system for planning that mirrors OEE's structure (Availability, Quality, and Performance), we can more effectively assess the manufacturing process's efficiency and its relationship to profitability.

Implementing a Unified Namespace (UNS) can significantly improve communication and collaboration between different teams, such as those working on the plant floor, data analysts, and IT staff. The UNS allows engineers at the edge to establish object/schema directly, streamlining the flow of information between parties and simplifying the IT role.

With a properly implemented UNS, data analysts can communicate directly with the plant floor staff, enabling better insights and more informed decision-making. Similarly, plant floor staff can inform analysts about the data needed, making the process more efficient.

By refining the KPIs and monitoring the correlations between OEE, planning scores, and net gross profit margins, we can make more informed decisions that lead to higher profitability and overall performance.

By understanding the connections between various factors, focusing on the development of a weighted scoring system, and aligning communication with an architecture that supports roles and responsibilities, we can effectively assess manufacturing performance and its relationship to net gross profit margins while improving overall efficiency.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
Example: Soda Packaging Operations

OEE Calculation:
Availability (A): Percentage of time the production line is operational and producing packages, taking into account downtime for maintenance, changeovers, or unplanned stoppages.
Quality (Q): Percentage of finished packages that meet quality standards, considering defects, damage, or other issues that require rework or disposal.
Performance (P): Percentage of the actual production rate compared to the optimal production rate, considering factors like machine speed, efficiency, and operator performance.
OEE = Availability √ó Quality √ó Performance

Schedule Adherence Calculation (Three-Part Scoring):
Adherence to Planned Time (T): Percentage of completed production orders that meet their planned time, taking into account delays, overtime, or changes in production schedule.
Adherence to Planned Sequence (S): Percentage of completed production orders that adhere to the planned sequence, considering changes in production order, material staging, or other deviations from the initial plan.
Adherence to Planned Quantity (Q): Percentage of completed production orders that meet their planned quantity, taking into account overproduction, underproduction, or changes in order quantities.
Schedule Adherence Score = Adherence to Planned Time √ó Adherence to Planned Sequence √ó Adherence to Planned Quantity

Author: douga.7429
Content:
Comparison of OEE and Schedule Adherence Scores:
Compare the calculated OEE and Schedule Adherence Scores for a given period, such as monthly or quarterly, and analyze how these factors relate to each other. Identify trends or patterns in the data, such as whether better schedule adherence leads to improved OEE or if there's a disconnect between the two.

Correlation with Net Gross Profit Margins:
Evaluate the correlation between OEE, Schedule Adherence Scores, and net gross profit margins for the same period. A strong correlation indicates that improvements in schedule adherence and OEE positively affect profitability. On the other hand, weak or negative correlations may suggest that other factors, such as inefficient planning or operational challenges, are impacting profits.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Performance and Scalability
Mosquitto:
lightweight and efficient, suitable for small to medium-sized deployments. Can handle thousands of concurrent connections on modest hardware, but its performance plateaus as scale increases, especially when requiring high throughput or low latency across a large number of devices.

HiveMQ Community Edition:
Scalability and high availability, making it well-suited for large-scale IoT deployments.


Security

Mosquitto:
Provides basic security features such as SSL/TLS for encrypted connections and simple authentication mechanisms (username/password).

HiveMQ Community Edition:
Offers advanced security features, including SSL/TLS, X.509 client certificate authentication, and extensive authorization controls, providing robust security out of the box.

Ease of Use and Setup

Mosquitto:
Simplicity and ease of setup, 

HiveMQ Community Edition:
HiveMQ's advanced features and scalability options introduce a steeper learning curve and potentially more complex setup compared to Mosquitto.

Community Support and Documentation
Mosquitto:
Large, active community and extensive documentation, easier to find help and resources for troubleshooting and development.

HiveMQ Community Edition:
Also has a strong community and good documentation, provides additional resources like webinars, tutorials, and a forum. 

Use Case Suitability

Mosquitto is best suited for:
Small to medium-sized IoT projects where simplicity, minimal resource consumption, and ease of setup are priorities.

HiveMQ Community Edition is best suited for:
Large-scale IoT applications requiring high throughput, low latency, and the ability to scale horizontally.

Author: r.pop
Content:
At the end of the day the goal of industry 4.0, in my opinion, is to deliver information to those that can act upon it the fastest. That information varies based on the persona. The key differences between a Plant manager and VP of Ops in terms of information usually has to do with granularity of the scope. For example, a Plant Manager is much more concerned with their plant, real-time information, the "Win the Shift, Win the Day, Win the Week" mindset. Their viewpoint is narrowed to their factory. A VP of Ops is typically more interested in Month/Quarter/Year results. Combining of Factory information with other business systems. Looking at data at a regional level, product line level, global level, etc.. 

It varies on the company, but in my experience of doing this for global manufacturers over the last 10 years. first as an end-user and now as a Consultant/Integrator, these are the things I've taken away. I don't want you to think that what I am saying is applicable to all companies/organizations, it's critical that we evaluate each customer on an individual level, and tailor the solution to their business. Implementing technology is not Digital Transformation, taking that technology and weaving it into the business with clearly defined goals and outcomes is what makes Digital Transformation. Like I mentioned above, it's fundamentally changing the way an organization does business, and it's our job as experts to guide that organization through that "journey" (take a drink).

Content: Hi, how do you/your costumers typically use their historians? (i'm looking for business cases where a problem got fixed by using a historian)

Author: _dyland
Content:
One very simple example:

3rd shift wasn't running a machine at optimal rates or with large gaps in production.

Before we had history, the manager would yell at the operator to stop making excuses. This caused all sorts of problems that resulted from this tension. While no one ever dug into the real issues that were causing the downtime in the first place.

After we had history, that same manager had proof about what caused the downtime. So instead of yelling at the employee about something that wasn't their fault, they found the problem with another part of the process and resolved it.

This decreased tension between the operator and management and identified a previously unknown bottleneck in the their process.

-

More concrete is that we work with the operators, managers, and engineers to create dashboards (on top of ad hoc ones) to help them see what is and was happening in the facility. Ex, A machine was running really well last week what changed? Oh, look the temperature of the incoming products is different, someone changed a setpoint, etc.

Even just generic process improvement stuff.

-

When you have enough "good" history, you can even start using it to make predictions.

Content:
Yes, getting to know and gain the trust of the operators is paramount. Show them you are there for them and to make their lives easier. OG operators have heard and seen it all, and they get very jaded by promises made but never delivered, or by technology that didn't solve the problems. 

I worked as an operator for years, and then in support of the production team, as a liaison with the OT and IT sides, as well as with the C-Suite on strategy and vision. 

Believe me when I say, the operators do not care how many letters you have after your name, or where your degree is from, or what it's in. Quite the contrary, they usually just roll their eyes and think, well here's another dumb college guy with no real understanding of what the realities are, and trust me they think ALL executives are idiots! 

It's just like when I was in the Marines, I was college educated, and wanted to go to Officer Candidate School, but first if I wanted to lead men into combat, I felt like I needed to know and understand the men I would be leading. So, I enlisted and went to bootcamp, and started as an E-1. I saw first hand what the divide was. All the enlisted men thought the officers were stupid, save for a few. 

The issue is a cultural divide between the groups that I've found is best mitigatd by getting in the trenches with the men and women doing the day-to-day. Know the shopfloor, know their problems, and then show them you are there to help solve those problems.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Mastering the concept of transaction records is essential for achieving traceability in complex systems. For a dairy example, consider when a raw milk truck arrives and receives a lot number, allowing for the traceability of all milk particulars. This milk is then pumped into a milk silo, generating a transaction record where Tanker X is logged as contributing to Batch 1A in Raw Milk Silo 1. The next step is pasteurization: the milk is transferred from Raw Milk Silo 1 to Pasteurized Milk Silo 1, creating a new transaction record for Batch 2A, derived from Batch 1A. This allows us to trace back to the original silo, and the milk tanker and includes details about the pasteurization process.

When a second tanker arrives, it is also pumped into Silo 1, initiating another transaction record and forming a new batch in Raw Milk Silo 1, named Batch 1B, which includes contributions from both Batch 1A and Truck 2. This leads to a new transaction at the pasteurizer, resulting in Batch 2B in the Pasteurized Milk Silo, which now comprises both Raw Milk Batches 1A and 1B.

Before pumping Batch 1B into the Silo, the milk was separated into skim and cream, generating two transaction records, 3A and 4A. The arrival of the second tanker triggered additional transaction records, updating the batches in the Skim and Cream tanks to 3B and 4B.

To manage this data, I would have used a separate table for each tank to log batches and associated transactions. Each transaction point should have a table listing the transaction number and the source and destination batches. This setup facilitates constructing a batch report, tracing each final batch back to all parent batches via the transaction records.

Given the complexity and potential for multiple routes, reworks, or reprocessing within larger systems, managing a single table can become challenging

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
One of the first projects I ever worked on was Power and Water monitoring for a food manufacturing plant.
We claimed that we saved the site 1 olympic sized swimming pool of water per shift just by monitoring the water consumption. The actual savings came from the site manager telling the shift leaders that they could not go home at the end of their shift unless the water usage was reading 0.
Making the water and power consumption visible is an easy first step. Adding context by combining data together for better KPIS and forecasting is a great second step.
All of this can be done with basic reporting tools, but soon enough you reach the limits of the source data. A classic example is "My machine operator forgets to click on a button to complete the production order before they go home, so the night shift, which should have been non-scheduled idle time, is showing as a production delay"
Once you go past the early low-hanging fruit, the solutions become more complex. You need more context, but you also need a system capable of being a transactional source system, not just a reporting tool. That's when you need something like a Manufacturing Data Hub

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
HighByte users do this. They use Intelligence Hub as a vendor-agnostic integration layer. They have built pipelines to support a wide variety of uses cases involving AGV, AMR, LGV, and other material handling assets. Vendors of these assets include JBT, E80, Gideon Brothers, etc. It's not uncommon for users to have multiple vendor solutions within the same site. And for each vendor, there is variability across models and model generations. Each will expose data over different interfaces or with different payloads.

These material handling use cases are interesting because it requires integrating with both the assets and their management software to get the full picture. The assets have telemetry data about their location, health, current task, etc. The management software, often with a SQL backend, have the information about intent and operational context of those assets. This is where all the data for the tasks, material, locations, etc reside.

Some use case patterns:
-Consistent data models across assets to support a unified view of vehicle status, inventory status, order status, batteries, chargers, dispatch, what's blocked, what's waiting, etc.
-Send run hours and open work orders in maintenance platforms (Infor MP2, Infor EAM). 
-Publish contextualized activity data to historians (AVEVA PI System) and data warehouses (Amazon Redshift). 
-Send program backups, log data, and detailed faults to storage (Amazon S3). 
-Create alerts for notification system if an asset has gone offline or is "stuck". 
-Share data between management platforms
-Share location data to prevent interference and conflicts

One of the more clever use cases I've seen involved the REST Data Server. There was a use case that required sharing location data between two different vendor platforms. The vendors did not want to cooperate with developing a direct connection. The user built APIs to remediate the differences.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
It can be daunting to get started. I think one of the challenges with an SI is understanding your business, all those assets, all those vendor solutions, and all the business requirements. You and your colleagues have a lot of the domain expertise.

I would recommend starting simple with one or two basic use cases. Figure out what transactions in SAP need to happen to make that work. Work backward from that. Break down the payload into individual attributes and determine where that data will come from in the material handling data sources. Try it with one group of similar assets and then another. Figure out the patterns and what can be re-used. This will create insight how to scale the solution. Keep iterating off of this.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Start with how users need data. How is the business organized and what is a logical way for users to browse/filter data? Where are they consuming data and are there any infrastructure constraints impacting them (e.g., network latency, WAN reliablity)? What apps/services are they going to use to consume this data? Is it a trend of values? Is it dataset for a particular business function? Are there any metrics that need to be calculated from data sets?

Work backwards to datasets that the above will depend on. This is your data at rest. This data could be stored in a relational database, a time series database, a historian, a datalake, a data warehouse, etc. Use what you already have and/or what is conducive to meeting the needs above. If you have a lot of process telemetry data that engineers to explore, trend, and analyze, a time series database or historian might work. If operations wants information about tracking discrete products, a relational database can make sense. The schema in these data stores are the semantics of your UNS. They should align with organizational requirements above.

Work backwards to what it takes to get data into these data stores. This is your data in motion. You could optionally employ a message broker to relay the latest values for data consumers that need it in a pub/sub fashion. Most consuming nodes about L2 will not.
